title: What are some ways to help the homeless? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thank you for your question, Linda and Mary. People experiencing homelessness do not have access to everyday common resources, like bus passes, meals between hours of local soup kitchen, showers and storage units for their stuff, and medical care. Cell phones are the only way they can get a call back from a potential employer or to know if their doctor’s appointment was changed. Cost of cellular and WiFi data is often difficult to maintain continuous service for cell phones when you are without a steady job. Lost IDs require proof of identification, and a copy of birth certificates can cost $50. Without computers, people without houses cannot get information about local services that provide housing vouchers, food stamps, and other services. People experience tears in tents and clothing, but they have no way to repair those items. While some people are able to continue their education, they still need to access writing pads, pens & pencils, and even reading glasses. These sound like every ordinary needs that you and I depend on, and it’s more a bigger need for the homeless. Shoes for families with children, healthy lunches, and even to go to a movie once a month or two — families in homelessness struggle. People who sleep in cars need fuel, or maybe oil and other automotive parts that keeps their only transportation operating. When you put all of this together, it shouldn’t be difficult to figure out the gaps of services in your community. Faith base groups need to accept responsibility to help the poor and the homeless, by thinking about sharing spaces for sheltering the homeless during extreme weather. My organization, Community Compassion Outreach, Inc., has identified gaps in services and we’ve used our programs to address those gaps. Resource lists and referrals to agencies that have funding to help is a critical part of helping the homeless navigate their community’s resources. Another step toward helping the homeless is to influence store managers to accept the homeless in their stores. The homeless are not the only thieves in our world, so why provide them just because they look unclean or are carrying a backpack over their shoulders. We’ve been aware that markets and stores will call the police when a homeless person is shopping. Many of the homeless have disability income and need to buy goods with their benefits. It’s horrible to learn that store managers can be so discriminatory of the homeless and the poor. Media needs to be more compassionate when reporting incidences involving homeless people. Exaggerated stories involving the homeless is the only thing that the public remembers. Changing the message is an important step toward helping people who have experienced some form of trauma. Homelessness is a trauma by itself; when compounded by new traumas, we should not expect the homeless to change overnight. That is the final recommendation I can make. Expectations and lack of patience by the public and service providers should be more realistic in order to avoid burn-out and frustrations when the people we try to help don’t change as quickly as we expect. High expectations of the population is unrealistic and unfair!
